segments.text: I got a call from the captain of the ship.
He wanted to see me.
I was just getting ready to go to bed.
Been up for probably 18 hours.
I walked up to his office, and he showed me a long teletype news release that had gone, had been released.
Now, there were lots of reporters aboard our ship, okay?
I don't have any idea how many.
but all kinds of reporters aboard our ship.
And they were able to send out over teletype news releases, as they should have been.
But he asked me, he says, did you talk to this guy?
Did you say this?
And I said, well, let me read it and see what it is first.
I said, first of all, I hadn't talked to anybody.
I read it, and
Here was a news release telling about what I had done that day, how I had gone into Vietnam, what I had done, and so on and so forth.
Biggest bunch of crap you have ever laid your eyes on.
Here's what we surmised had happened.
There is a bulletin board on the ship that has the plan of the day, and it has a command roster on there.
And I was the senior Marine aboard this ship.
And I was CO of troops.
My battalion was aboard.
There was two and a half helicopter squadrons aboard.
But I was a senior Marine.
And so this guy, wanting to get a story, assumed that I had gone ashore.
The battalion that actually did the work had gone,

off of another ship he was not aboard my ship this guy took my name and blt19 was what i commanded at that time and he simply wrote a story out purely out of his own head now if he had not been stupid he would have known that i had not gone ashore
What I'm saying is these young reporters made their money.
That was their job.
I mean, they didn't, a lot of them, didn't get paid unless they had so many column inches or so many minutes of video time.
When I was in Vietnam proper the first time,
Most of the time, we weren't bothered with reporters too much, because we were really doing the mundane thing.
And who wants to hear about the type thing that we were doing?
But when we got to Khe Sanh, that was another matter.
Boy, they used to fly in there on anything that they could get a ride on.
And they'd get off of one of those airplanes, and they'd grab the first guy they could find, hopefully, to see a responsible person.
And they wanted your name, your organization, but that really is about all they wanted, because they wrote the rest of their story on crap.
They already had their minds made up what they were going to write about, and that's how you get
So much of the stuff that I said, you know, you would think that we would have found 300 people in our barbed wire every morning because of the assaults on the base.
And it just didn't happen.
Well, who wants to write about they spent their night in their bunker being shelled by artillery and rockets all night?
That doesn't read very well.
And as a result of that, they didn't want to write it.
But the media was terrible.
I can't emphasize that enough.
They'd get in your way.
They wanted to be in places where they shouldn't be.
I kind of like the way General Schwarzkopf handled them in Desert Storm.
And I realize that that might sound as though there's a conflict in believing that we have the right to do all these things and then we're going to restrict.
I do not think that there should be censors per se.
There should be
available at some point all the information so that history can be correct.
But there should not be information that would allow, well, the latest is over in Somalia, allow the press to be waiting when the Marines land.
Now, as it turned out, that didn't hurt anything.
But it could have.
It could have created all sorts of things.
And my position is this.
Why should I place my Marines in added danger just so some jerk can write a column, can be the first one to get some information back to a newspaper?
Now, does it matter whether that news was shown on today's 6 o'clock news or day after tomorrow?
Not one iota.
What is important is that it be truthful if and when it does get to the news.
Not when it gets there, but that it is the truth when it gets there.
I suppose handling the media has got to rank almost equal in importance to your fire support plan.
And that's terrible.
A commander should not have to worry about newspaper people.
He should be able to concentrate on saving the lives of his people.
That should be his most important mission.
And it's not anymore.
And that's terrible.
And I won't forgive him for that.
From some of the things that you've indicated, I think you feel that a lot of people misunderstand Vietnam.
No doubt about it.
What would you like for future generations to understand about Vietnam?
Well, that's a pretty broad question.
I would like for people to understand that a large
number of Americans went to a country that they didn't understand.
They went there because the commander in chief sent them there.
And that probably 99% of them did a tremendous job.
And they were as brave as any other American fighting force has ever been.
They did this without the support back home that all other wars had had.
And that includes Corita, too.
Basically, our people in Korea were supported back home.
That it was predominantly a guerrilla war, one of which really US forces are not well suited for in the way of organization, equipment, so on and so forth.
And that they did their duty as they saw it.
I don't think that the vast majority of us have any reason to believe that we have to share the blame, the responsibility for the few like the My Lai Massacre and so forth.
Those were criminal acts done by criminals.
And I don't think the United States Army, for instance, should feel as though there's a special responsibility or a black mark on them for this.
This was done by an inept criminal.
And they finally did try and so forth.
But what would I want the people to believe?
That young men did a tough, dirty job.
It's always the young men that really pay the ultimate price.
I was 36 years old.
when I was there the first time.
I wasn't a kid.
It's the young 18, 19, 20 year old man that pays the price.
But I think it's part of that wall I alluded to before.
They stand as a part of
what we are as people.
And they have every reason to be proud of it.
And we have stood up against what we thought was wrong, generally referred to as communism for the last 50 years.
The things that we've done has not necessarily been popular and it has never been pleasant.
And the brunt of that has always been on the shoulder of the young men.
But that's what makes us a great nation.
And I think, if you'll allow, people often
get the wrong idea when they think of and talk about freedom.
Maybe the word itself lends itself to that.
Because it starts off with free and leads a lot of people to think that it didn't cost anything.
That's not true.
It cost a lot.
And you know who it cost?
The young man, the young soldier, the young sailor, the young Marine.
The air effort, which I don't have any firsthand knowledge of, of course, in this war, probably is different from any other.
in that almost all of our prisoners of war were aviators, were pilots.
In other wars, with the exception of the early part of the European war, aviators were fairly safe.
And large numbers were not taken prisoners and so forth.
And we haven't touched on that, but you know, I think the people who paid the greatest price of all were our prisoners of war.
And almost all of those were officers, and almost all of them were eight years.
I have a great deal of respect for them, for what they had to go through.
If you allow me to just go back a bit to the media, what the media has done to the families of what we now still show is missing in action is absolutely criminal.
Absolutely criminal.
They go over and they get pictures and so on and so forth and they get little bits and pieces and then go back and prey on the families of these guys who have long since been dead.
It is absolutely criminal.
I cannot fathom any

responsible military officer who ever would have had any kind of intelligence information about us having live people over there that would have ever been quiet about it or not taken appropriate action.
And I cannot fathom our politicians

And by that, I mean our presidents, the two presidents that were involved in this ever making any kind of behind the scene deal that would have left, you know, X number of our prisoners over there for peace.
I mean, I reject that outright.
First of all, he can't do it in the vacuum.
There would have been lots of
Not lots, but there would have been enough military people in on that sort of thing.
And I have enough pride in them.
They'd have never stood still for it.
But the media, and this is a small part of the media.
are going to suck this thing for as long as they can make money on it.
And if you think that there's any other motivation behind what they're doing than money, then you're crazy as a bed bug.
It is money-oriented.
And it's making these people suffer again and again and again.
They've suffered enough.
Leave them alone.
Anyway.
Is there anything that I haven't asked you about that you just want to talk about?
Well, I alluded to the prisoners.
The suffering that they went through is almost
unimaginable.
If you haven't read some of the books that some of these guys have written, you should do so.
Because there were some real heroes.
And I suspect that for most of us,
Whatever effect that the Vietnam War had on us has probably dissipated to the point to where it's just one of those things that happened in our earlier life.
But I don't think it's done this with the prisoners yet.
I suspect that they're still paying for a lot of that.

I guess the only other thing that I would say is that there was an awful lot written and there was a lot of people got on the so-called bandwagon about the post-trauma syndrome that a lot of the Vietnamese veterans suffered from.
I don't know.
There was a time when I thought that entire thing was a bunch of bunk.
And I truly felt that most of the people that was claiming that was just doing so for a free ride.
But I guess the reason I arrived at that conclusion is that at one point there was about 550,000 men over there.
But out of that 550,000 men that was in Vietnam,
Only about 100,000 are what you would actually call combat troops.
The rest of them were eating three hot meals a day out of a mess hall, were sleeping in either a tent that had been specially prepared with wooden decks and so on and so forth,

that were going to px's and clubs and going to movies every night so the vast majority of the experiences about four-fifths of the stories that you would get would be totally different from what i told you because it was from the you know work eight or ten hours a day and then sleep the rest of the time in reasonable safety
Every now and then, the Viet Cong would come around and would throw a few mortar rounds in some of these big bases.
Some of the big bases down around Saigon had swimming pools, Olympic-sized swimming pools.
Now, I don't put any credence whatsoever to the experience that the four-fifths of the people involved in that sort of thing have
The young soldier who was in the combat unit probably worked as hard and endured as much hardship as 90% of them ever did in other wars.
So to that group of people, I truly take my hat off.
To the four-fifths, and they're the ones that do the most talking,
and tell the most exaggerated stories about Vietnam, I say, it's a bunch of garbage.
I have sat and listened to these stories in the past.
And finally, you know, just saying, oh, by the way, what outfit were you with when you were in Vietnam?
And in almost every case,
It would be some headquarters guy that got three hot meals a day and slept between sheets.
So I don't put any stop for it whatsoever.
I can tell you this, and this is all that I know for sure, all the other something that I've been told.
But I know for a fact that the people of the 2nd Battalion 26 Marines
in the seven months that I was there did not have one single solitary day off.
Not one.
They were up patrolling or doing something until we got to Quezon when we just sat there all day long on patrol or ambush or something all night long.
Probably did not average
more than three or four hours sleep.
Now, I don't know what kind of effect, long-term effect, that had on them.
Probably not good.
I finally did come to the conclusion that some of that's real.
But the vast majority of it's not.
The vast majority of it is not.
I appreciate this so much.
